title: Underwater Visual Census Protocol
content:
## Underwater Visual Census (UVC) Protocol

### Purpose
This protocol describes standardized methods for conducting underwater visual census surveys to estimate fish abundance and diversity on coral reefs.

### Equipment Required
- SCUBA or snorkeling equipment
- Underwater slate and pencils
- Transect tape (50m)
- Quadrat frame (if sampling benthos)
- Underwater camera
- Depth gauge
- Safety equipment (SMB, whistle)

### Survey Design

1. **Site Selection**:
   - Stratify by habitat type (reef flat, slope, crest)
   - Use random or systematic placement
   - Minimum 3 replicate transects per site

2. **Transect Layout**:
   - Deploy 50m transect tape parallel to reef contour
   - Mark start point with GPS (surface)
   - Record depth at start, middle, and end

### Survey Procedure

3. **Belt Transect Method**:
   - Swim at constant speed (approximately 10 min per 50m)
   - Record all fish within 2.5m on each side (5m total width)
   - Survey area = 50m × 5m = 250 m²

4. **Fish Recording**:
   - Identify to lowest taxonomic level possible
   - Estimate size class (TL): <5cm, 5-10cm, 10-20cm, 20-30cm, >30cm
   - Count individuals; estimate schools >20 fish
   - Note behavior (feeding, schooling, resting)

5. **Environmental Data**:
   - Record visibility (horizontal distance)
   - Estimate percent coral cover
   - Note current strength and direction
   - Record water temperature

### Quality Control

6. **Observer Training**:
   - Practice fish identification before surveys
   - Conduct calibration exercises between observers
   - Document observer experience level

7. **Data Validation**:
   - Cross-check identifications with underwater photos
   - Flag unusual sightings for verification
   - Calculate inter-observer variability

### Data Analysis
- Calculate density (individuals per m²)
- Calculate species richness per transect
- Use PERMANOVA for community comparisons

### References
- English et al. (1997) Survey Manual for Tropical Marine Resources
- CMLRE Reef Monitoring Guidelines 2024
